The course is very useful, it helps us a lot in improving software skills and also in other courses we will need the knowledge in this course.

This class is excellent, very instructive. I learnt a lot and improved my skills in programming. 

An improvement for this class is that the class note for R can be present using Rmarkdown which will be more clear and easy to run.

All else are perfect!

can we add python?
SAS and R are useful. But love to learn Python as well.
Python is widely used in the industry but there is no Python course in the department.
good

strength: well organized
weakness: too short

professor is professional and energetic. Help students solve problems timely. 
Suggest to provide students more time to understand concept learned in class.

Although with a name of "Advanced Programming", this course is still teaching basic level content. I was hoping the course could let students using those programming to work on some real advanced projects which are more related to real research, not so many homework that you need to follow the instruction from the instructor to get the points. 

I couldn't believe the debugging techniques were never taught during the whole semester. I don't know how students will do their future complicated projects using the programming language without debugging skills.

Students need to be very careful to read the instructor's homework description in order to submit an answer that is exactly what the instructor is expecting to get the points. Programming is an art and flexible, so it should be a fun class to do, not afraid of losing points so I have to use the same way as the instructor expecting. 

Taking much longer time to get feedback from the homework, always wait couple weeks to get the grade for a homework. The instructor was hoping to get understanding from students regarding her busy schedule, but I don't think it is a mutual understanding from both parties. 

A timed exam for programming? This is not Hackathon!

This course was fast paced and there is a lot of material covered. I felt like I learned a lot of new skills that I haven't gotten from any other course. However, the midterm and final exams did not seem like a fair assessment of my skills or knowledge or ability to problem solve. Rather, it seemed like a race against the clock. Due to how the course was structured, the midterm was a cumulative exam on SAS, and the final was a cumulative exam on R. Both exams were allotted 2 hours to answer 4-6 questions. 2 hours did not feel like enough time to allow students to show their full abilities. I think that it would be a better measure of our abilities if either (a) we are given 3-4 hours of time per exam so that it is not our ability to type quickly, but our knowledge with the program itself that is being tested. Or (b) if the same format of questions is given along with the cumulative homework assignments and there is no formal exam process, essentially making it a take home exam. I did appreciate the format of the exam questions - it is one thing to know how to code, and another to know how to correct errors in code or make code more efficient. So the exam questions themselves are a good measure, but the time limit does not fully allow students to work effectively, and it means that a lot of points can be lost simply due to time.

The strength is I learn lots of practical programming codes which are useful for my research. The weaknesses is the teacher didn't teach you how to debug and the homework and exam is kind of excess what she taught us.
Class notes are straightforward and very useful to keep.
I learned a lot from this course. I liked the weekly homeworks because they helped me solidify what we had discussed in lecture.

This course was great. I learned a lot about SAS and R. In particular how to make my codes reproducible and more generalizable. As a non-biostats student, I think this course will help me program my analysis more efficiently. I think a challenge for me was understanding the applicability of some of the content taught in the R component of the course. While I understand simulations are important in clinical trial design, we did too much of it in the end portion of the course. As a CDE student, I would have loved to learn to program my own regressions (i.e. having multiple exposures and risk factors), power calculations and bivariate analysis code. For example, I would benefit tremendously from writing a code that outputs tables that journals normally want to see like forest plots, or ORs tables, or tables with point estimates, confidence intervals etc. Writing a code that accounted for study design (i.e. case control vs cohort vs clinical trial) and then ran all my regressions would have been more useful for the non-biostats students. While I think I am able to use what we learned to do the things I describe above, having this be class examples makes it easier to understand the material and programming in R. It becomes more applicable to what I am used to. The fact that we did simulations for a lot of the assignments made the course more challenging, and actually led to some of my classmates from SBS and CDE to drop the course. They didn't understand the relevance of programming. The SAS component did achieve all these things as the material was very relevant to what I normally do when I have a data set that I will analyze. I think learning similar dataset management techniques in R would have been more useful for the non-biostats students. I wish the R and SAS classes were provided in separate courses over 1 year where students can engage with their own personal datasets and learn each program pretty in depth. Leaving the course with a code that works for my specific type of dataset would have been fabulous, specially because I work with very large population-based cancer datasets and clinical trial datasets.
The course was pretty good overall. I think some of the material (i.e. PROC SQL) was taught in a very rushed manner
good
I have learned a lot from this class. I enjoyed going to the lectures, and the homework offered the right among of challenge.
This class should have a prerequisite course requirement.
good

Overall it's a good class. Dr. Esserman is very patient and she explained the code line by line. But the homework instructions should be more clear. Should teach students how to debug their code in class.

It was a great course and I enjoyed the material. However, it should be made very clear at the beginning of the class that it is a VERY challenging course and that a comfort with R is necessary to do well.
This course is really useful for practicing the data cleaning and programming, however, the midterm and the final which require writing code in less than 2 hours are really stressful.

This course is well-structured and taught. It laid a solid foundation on SAS and R programming. I think it would be better if the professor could teach the lab sessions herself and let the TA grade the homework assignments.
the materials are arranged in a very clear manner, and the materials are really useful.
Very fundamental knowledge and application of R and SAS, but still a little unfriendly to people without programming experiment

The course is helpful.  Material is useful in real world application.

Strength: clear note, helpful labs, clear homework

Weakness: lack of real-world project, too strict scoring policy for homework

Improve: change the big homework into small project, somewhat loosen the scoring policy of code
The lecture itself is once per week, two hours every time. I wish we could meet twice a week and have a shorter lecture so that we can focus more.
Alright class. The SAS component is painful and there are too many assignments.

I think the course covered important basics of SAS and R, but I wished that the exams were assignments instead because in real life we wouldn't really be asked to code under time constraint, especially for those of us with no prior coding background.

I think the course is an excellent crash course in advanced statistical programming.  I thought that the 2nd half of the course for R is more organized than the SAS part.  

I felt that some of the initial HWs for SAS involved so much material that we did not cover or was simple too advanced.  For instance, the 'missover' keyword (or another similar keyword) was not discussed but it was needed for a homework problem.  The course is really difficult for the most part.  But the TF helped a lot of those with less programming background.  I believe learning could be maximized if they were two TFs for extra office hours help.
The R part of the course is noticeably more difficult compared to the SAS part. It would be better if the lab part could provide more examples that would help with the homework.

This course was excellent. I did not have any background in SAS or R and made a huge improvement by the end of the term. This may be why I spent so much time completing the assignments for this course, but I think compared to the other courses, comparatively there is a higher workload for this course. I think it would be helpful for students to be able to drop the lowest homework grade or to have at least one fewer assignment during the last week of class. Nevertheless, this course was outstanding and worth the effort.
Is a very useful class and I like it.

course was really helpful but workload of the assignments are not the same, some weeks we spend couple of hours studying but in between 3-5th and 9-11th homeworks we spend so much time, plus studied for the final. Especially during midterm and finals week assignments should not be that complicated, or big homeworks might way more than 30%.
This course is very useful and I would highly recommend it.
She is a very excellent professor! Each class she teaches very useful skills in a well-organized SAS or R file, we could easily understand every details. And she replies to our questions patiently!
The instructor is very helpful, and always replies our emails very timely. she's putting a lot effort and explaining things really clearly.

interactive teaching
very clear instruction
easy to follow

can go faster
good

strength: very patient and responsible
weakness: careless

excellent and professional. 
help students solve problems in office hour which is very helpful!

Should have focused more real advanced programming skill - how to debug, how to do some cool project using the programming language. 

Should have created more flexible and fun environment for students to learn, discuss and enjoy. Not focusing on how to follow the instruction of homework to get credits. 

Should grade all the homework in timely manner. if the instructor is too busy, why not let the TF grade them?

Nice and patient;
Prepare well for the class

Professor Esserman was very prompt to reply to any questions and she was very willing to explain processes and help frame our thinking about how to tackle problems. She was approachable and easy to work with during office hours or over email if there were any questions.

I wish she can grade our homework on time and provide us feedback about homework. Also gives us a clear note about the grading system. She teaches us a lot of informatics knowledge. But sometimes the gradings are too harsh. Also, if she wants us to think critically outside class, she should also provide us with the resource to learn.

This professor's instructions on the assignments can be very unclear. The gradings were unfair too, the instructor only grades based on the end result, which means that if the first line of code failed to get a dataset imported for some reason then all the steps below that are actually important and could take hundreds of lines would be completely ignored and the assignment would be given a zero. Other times, the instructor also would overlook some steps in the assignment and took points off because she thought she didn't see that, then you would always need to pay attention to double-checking with her to get the points back. The instructor is also very impolite in emails.
Dr. Esserman was incredibly helpful and friendly during her office hours. I found her easy to approach, and I always left office hours feeling more confident about my homework.
Professor Esserman is responsible instructor who gives clear explanations of the course materials and timely feedback.

The professor was above excellent. She was flexible and always available to help students in need. When not available in person, she was very responsive over email. This was extremely important for me. I enjoyed this class, despite it being the most challenging one I took this semester. Programming is an excellent skill to have and the professor helped demystify functions and reproducible code in R.
strict but lovely
Professor Esserman is a great professor. She explains things very clearly during her lectures, which is very helpful. She is also very approachable, responding to emails promptly.
She is a really great instructor and the class is really great.
good

Dr. Esserman is very patient and I like her teaching style. the code provided for students are very detailed and the comments are informative. It would be great if Dr. Esserman can give a more timely feedback for assignments and be more clear when giving the assignment instructions.
I loved Denise! I felt so bad asking such simple questions during her office hours but she was always wonderfully kind and willing to help me through the homework assignments.
Denise is really patient and helpful, she responds to emails very quickly.

Professor Denise is very patient, kind and helpful, willing to answer every trivial question. The materials were well-organized, assignments were designed to practice and enhance our understanding of the programming language, and the exams linked tightly with what we had learned.
Great instructor
Very patient and familiar with the use of SAS & R, could give good explanations of how to programme.

Very strict,  hard working, helpful

Strength: clear speaking, time contributing, good effort

Weakness: sometimes not easy to communicate
Professor Esserman is very organized and knowledgeable and I admire her very much.
Professor Esserman taught the course effectively by covering the critical coding skills in both SAS and R.
Dr. Esserman explained the codes well and is helpful during office hours. She also gives clear examples that helped me learn the two languages quickly.

Really tough grader.  I have taken quite a few CS and programming courses, and to date, Dr. Esserman is the toughest grader I've ever had.  But she means well.  And is very helpful in office hours.  I mentioned in the previous part that learning could be maximized if they were two TFs for extra office hours help. An alternative to that is for Dr Esserman to have two separate office hours.

I cannot praise Professor Esserman enough. She is very hardworking and committed to helping her students learn. The course materials she developed are very thorough and she was able to cover a great variety of topics in a short time. She is a great instructor!

The instructor is clear and helpful.
Sometimes it is hard to follow because of the way the instructor designed the course materials.
She is a really great instructor and so helpful during office hours. Everything was so clear and I learned a lot from this class.

Professor Esserman is very approachable and willing to help students. It's a bit difficult to ask questions during class since it's a big class but the professo ris definitely accessible outside of class.
Great skills learnt at this course.
Strongly recommend. I learned a lot.
Perfect, I'll recommend.

introductory course for SAS and R
recommend for students without SAS/R background.
may be too easy for students already know SAS and R
good
Yes. Coding is pretty interesting.

This is not a well designed course overall, at least should have changed the name of the course. I wouldn't recommend the course to other students who really want to learn advanced programming skills in SAS or R. Students could just use online materials to get the same level of knowledge instead of spending a whole semester sitting in the class and finishing those homework but worrying about not getting any credit if you didn't follow the instructor's mind.
If you have background in SAS and R, and want to learn more efficient ways of coding and programming, this course is an excellent way to do so.
I will recommend it cautiously. It's a good course. But it will drag down your overall grades.
I would not recommend this course.
I would recommend this course to anyone seeking to learn to code in SAS and R.
Highly recommend
I would recommend this course to students who want to code their analysis more efficiently and faster. It is a challenging course, so students need to be ready to seek as much help as they need.

Students systematically learn how to code in R and SAS. I highly recommend this class to other students.

good

I will recommend this course to students with no or little experience with R and SAS. This course is designed to teach fundamental programming knowledge and the topics are very related to statistical analysis
Would recommend it but would definitely emphasize that it is a very difficult course!

I would recommend this course if you have background of SAS and R, it is a really great and useful course for the advanced application of SAS and R in solving the real problem. For those who haven't used SAS or R before, this course will be a little hard.
Highly recommend this course if you want to learn SAS and R languages.
A really useful and reasonable class
Very useful, I would recommend it.
Yes. This provide very important and helpful info for the graduate learning
It is very useful. Although it is hard, the course is worth taking since we students would need the skill in the future.
Alright class. The SAS component is painful and there are too many assignments.
The SAS and R coding learned in this class will be very helpful for data analysis jobs. I will recommend this class to another student.
An excellent crash course in advanced statistical programming.  But beware, this will be a demanding, time-consuming course with its weekly homework and end-of-module projects!
I would recommend it because both SAS and R are useful tools for any type of data management.
This course teaches advanced concepts in programming with SAS and R. I would strongly recommend to another student.
